comment._content:
Great photo,(and a lovely bicycle too).
Looks like a team with players from all walks of life.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Something odd about the bicycle - the chainring and chain are on the 'wrong' side. At first I thought the photo was the wrong way round, but the buttons on the shirts etc are OK so it must be the bike which is unusual. From oldbike.wordpress.com/1893-safety-bicycle/ Early safeties featured either left-hand or right-hand chains. There was no particular advantage to mounting it on either side. But, with the 1890s boom in bicycle sales, the industry had to standardize cycle components. By 1895, right-hand chains had become the standard. Almost unheard of nowadays, but it is possible to do it if you want to be weird different sheldonbrown.org/gunnar/

comment.author: 39191857@N05
comment._content: Interesting shot, the belts, or lack of belts on display, the fact that the gentlemen sitting down all had flannels obviously denoting status, the use of ties or cloth as belts and none actually showing braces?  The bicycle is typical of a fixed wheel up to the 60's - the bare bones and little else though the chain looks very slack for a fixed wheel.  Sir Richard really piled on the weight in the short time between photos.

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] Track racing bikes (as ridden by Chris Hoy) still don't have brakes. It's safer if no-one slows down suddenly, and on the track there are no unexpected obstacles to stop for. There is a fixed-wheel technique known as 'leg-braking' whereby you pull back on the pedals with your legs to slow down (easier if your shoes are fixed to the pedals in some way). You can even ride backwards (not recommended on the road).

comment.author: 29809546@N00
comment._content: Last year a friend of mine rode 1200km in 90 hours on a 1900 Peugot (he still has the receipt). His bike has a back -pedal brake which is not very reliable and a spoon brake on the front wheel which is particularly ineffective. And it's far too big for him, so the 'heel power' technique wouldn't work. And he rode with a specially-grown authentic-looking 1900s moustache,. with a flat cap of the era, and on what looked like the original saddle. In B&W he wouldn't look out of place on the NLI photostream. Here he is on Portocéan's photostream.

comment.author: 63163769@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/]
True, if a design is not broke, don't fix it, however it seems to me that it is very rare that a 19th Century invention is so well designed that it is virtually unchanged in the 21st Century.
Look at the design of the automobile over the same period. (Granted, the bicycle is a much simpler machine).

comment.author: 47290943@N03

comment.author: 14302637@N08
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johnspooner] That vintage bike website is great, especially "Bicycle Erotica" www.oldbike.eu/museum/?page_id=1641 A vintage bicycle enthusiast was out for a walk when he met a fellow vintage bike enthusiast who was riding toward him on a wonderful old bicycle. The first vintage enthusiast was stunned. ‘Where did you get that fantastic machine?’ he asked. ‘You’ll never believe it,’ said the second enthusiast. ‘I was walking home yesterday, minding my own business, when a beautiful woman rode up to me on this bike. She threw the bike onto the ground, took all her clothes off, and said: ‘Take what you want.’ The first vintage enthusiast nodded approvingly. ‘Good choice …her clothes probably wouldn’t have fitted you anyway.’

comment.author: 83041814@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/blackpoolbeach] Probably not a track bike, for the simple reason that there were no velodromes in Ireland at the time. In fact, this is probably just a freewheel bike (freewheels were introduced in 1898) with a coaster brake in the rear hub. Most bikes looked like this in 1902.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/thiskidgotmoxie] While not quite a velodrome, this cycle track was opened in the People's Park, Waterford in May 1891...
